title: Grubhub, Marriott International, Abbott Laboratories: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Grubhub Inc.

title: House Changes Rules to Allow Proxy Voting During Pandemic
summary: Democratic proposal passes after talks with Republicans broke down. WASHINGTON-The House approved a slate of rules changes that will allow lawmakers to cast votes by proxy during the coronavirus pandemic, a historic step that Democrats cast as pragmatic but that Republicans warned could alter the nature of Congress.

title: Virus Drives Rapid Declines in Factory Output, Retail Sales
summary: April U.S. retail sales fell 16.4% and manufacturing output 13.7%, both records. Consumers pulled back on spending and factories cut output at the fastest pace in decades as lockdowns to contain the coronavirus pandemic hit the U.S. economy.

title: How WHO Lost Its Way
summary: The U.N. agency was more effective when its mandate was limited.. Some change inevitably will come to the World Health Organization (WHO) after its deadly failures during the Covid-19 pandemic. But real reform will require more than technocratic tweaks, and member states should focus on fundamental questions about the agency's purpose.

title: Richard Gilder
summary: His ideas and philanthropy helped to revive New York and Central Park.. At a moment when New York City is facing an historic challenge from the novel coronavirus, it is worth remembering Richard Gilder, who did much to pull the city out of the economic and social crises of the 1970s and 1980s.

title: U.S. Moves to Cut Off Chip Supplies to Huawei
summary: New restriction stops foreign semiconductor manufacturers whose operations use U.S. software and technology from shipping products to Huawei without first getting a license from U.S. officials. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration said it would impose export restrictions designed to cut off Chinese telecom-equipment maker Huawei Technologies Co. from overseas suppliers, threatening to ignite a new round of U.S.-China economic tensions.

title: Emmet Sullivan vs. the D.C. Circuit
summary: Another precedent that rebuts the judge's ruling in the Flynn case.. Federal Judge Emmet Sullivan has refused to accept the prosecution and defense agreement to drop the charges against Michael Flynn for lying to the FBI, despite a mountain of law saying he doesn't have the authority. We wrote Friday about Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's recent ruling that cuts against his decision to solicit outside briefs. And now we're reminded of another precedent that is even more on point about the judge's wayward logic.

title: Why Senators Shouldn't Pick Stocks
summary: They're 'as feckless as the rest of us at stock picking,' a study says.. The FBI executed a search warrant on Senator Richard Burr this week and seized his cellphone. The North Carolina Republican has acknowledged that he sold at least $628,000 of stock in February, during the run-up to the coronavirus crash. But Mr. Burr insists he did not break the law.

title: Brazilian Health Minister Quits as Coronavirus Infections Rise
summary: In some countries, political discord is hampering efforts to control the epidemic. Brazil's health minister, Nelson Teich, resigned Friday after just four weeks in office, leaving South America's biggest country without a top health official as the coronavirus pandemic rages there and across much of Latin America.

title: Orlando Is Reopening. Persuading Tourists to Return Is Harder.
summary: Resume Subscription. ORLANDO, Fla.-Florida has begun reopening for business, but this tourist mecca faces a grinding road to recovery.

title: The Lockdown Skeptic They Couldn't Silence
summary: Targeted for censorship in March, Aaron Ginn is becoming an influential voice in cities, states and Washington.. Does a pandemic demand the strong medicine of censorship? Social-media companies seem to think so. They're taking steps to control speech in the name of combating the spread of medical misinformation. Facebook employs "fact checkers" to review posts, makes those that don't pass their test harder to find, and directs users to purportedly reliable sources like the World Health Organization. YouTube has taken down videos it deems inconsistent with science. Twitter plans to add warning labels to tweets that don't pass muster with "subject-matter experts, such as public health authorities."

title: Coronavirus Restrictions Ease Further in U.S.
summary: Reports on retail sales, industrial production document economic damage; White House details new vaccine effort. Coronavirus-related restrictions eased further Friday in parts of the U.S., as new data showed the economic damage caused by lockdowns designed to limit the contagion, and the White House detailed an effort to pursue a vaccine.

title: 'Up All Night' Review: Headlines, Nonstop
summary: Forty years ago, Ted Turner's revolutionary Cable News Network changed the way America gets television news. What was once a half-hour nightly appointment is now water from the tap.. If a Mount Rushmore of American journalism is ever carved out of some Western mountain, Ted Turner's gap-toothed grin is unlikely to be up there next to Hearst, Pulitzer and whichever other worthy makes the cut. Yet the often-buffoonish billionaire "Mouth of the South" is as responsible as any other pioneer for the way Americans get their news today.

title: 'Lincoln on the Verge' Review: Odyssey to the Inaugural
summary: The president-elect's trip from Springﬁeld, Ill., to Washington, D.C., was fraught with peril, both personal and political.. When Abraham Lincoln began his fraught inaugural journey to Washington in 1861 with an "affectionate farewell" to his neighbors in Springfield, Ill., the orator had been silent for months. As if animated by both destiny and reality, he summoned divine assistance without venturing specifics about how he planned to save the fractured country.

title: 'Signatures' Review: In His Good Books
summary: Brief lives of writers who signed copies of their works for the author, a very English man of letters.. 'There will always be an England," once the safest of safe generalizations, is now in need of serious qualification. An England doubtless there always will be, but England today is sadly diminished from the England that once bred Anglophiles round the world, myself among them. This earlier England was known for its courage, its elegance, its grandeur. This was the England that in the past century produced Winston Churchill, Evelyn Waugh, Rebecca West, Hugh Trevor-Roper; the England whose traditions, in dress, wit, intellectual life, were admirable in so many ways.

title: Stimulus Talks: How Democrats, Republicans, Trump Split on Coronavirus Bill
summary: House passage of its package should spur negotiations with Senate, Trump team. The three sets of negotiators in the next round of talks over another coronavirus-related stimulus package hold sharply different positions on a number of issues. House Democrats are voting on their bill Friday. Senate Republicans and the White House have staked out different stances, but they haven't released formal plans.

title: Trump Hasn't Ruled Out More Aid for States, Economic Adviser Says
summary: Kevin Hassett says president doesn't want aid to constitute a bailout for problems that predated coronavirus pandemic. WASHINGTON-President Trump hasn't ruled out additional economic relief for states and cities grappling with the coronavirus pandemic, as long as it doesn't constitute what he considers a "bailout," White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett said Friday.

title: One of America's Remotest States Makes Remote Learning Work
summary: The Alaska district where my kids attend school has ensured they don't miss out on an education.. Palmer, Alaska

title: Notable & Quotable: Mitch Daniels Stands Timothy Leary on His Head
summary: 'Turn off, tune out, drop in.'. From Purdue University President Mitch Daniels's 2020 commencement speech, May 13:

title: The Chinese Challenge to the U.S.-Israel Relationship
summary: Beijing brings investment dollars, but also tensions with America.. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met on Wednesday with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem and warned that further Israeli economic linkage with China will hurt relations with the U.S. Coming from an administration far warmer toward Israel than any in the past, that message packs a punch.

title: Biden Had Half as Much Cash as Trump at End of April
summary: Mr. Biden's advisers said his campaign and the Democratic National Committee ended the month with $103 million on hand. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden's presidential campaign apparatus ended April with less than half as much money in the bank as President Trump's team, figures released Friday showed, as the former vice president's team promised a hiring spree to come in battleground states.

title: The Pentagon Is a 900-Pound Crybaby
summary: In a fight over 5G wireless spectrum, the military worries it won't be able to bomb America.. Chairman Ajit Pai at the Federal Communications Commission has picked a fight with an adversary that buys main battle tanks by the gross. Its inventory of nuclear weapons at last count totaled 6,185.

title: Stocks Recover, But Finish the Week With Losses
summary: Retail sales in April fell by a record amount. U.S. stocks edged higher Friday but notched weekly declines after a wide range of data this week revealed the sharp contraction in economic activity across the nation.

title: Treasury Yields Rise on Consumer Sentiment Data
summary: Yields, however, remain near the all-time lows they reached in March, reflecting a dismal outlook amid the coronavirus pandemic. U.S. government bond prices edged lower Thursday after new data suggested consumers are feeling better about the economy than economists had expected.

title: States Are Reopening With No Clear Picture of Coronavirus Cases
summary: Across the country, lockdowns are easing. But inadequate testing, varied reporting standards and a lack of coordination make it hard to get a handle on case counts and national trends. One week after North Carolina began allowing businesses to reopen this month, the number of people who tested positive for Covid-19 surged by nearly 500 in a single day.

title: DOJ, States Likely to Bring Antitrust Suits Against Google
summary: Both the federal and state investigations are focused on Google's ad business. WASHINGTON-Both the Justice Department and a group of state attorneys general are likely to file antitrust lawsuits against Alphabet Inc.'s Google-and are well into planning for litigation, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: What a Small Chip Fab Really Buys
summary: TSMC's new Arizona plant will be limited in scale and expensive to operate but will pay off politically. Anyone in the business of making chips knows that little things can make a big difference.

title: Hong Kong's SenseTime Considers $1 Billion Capital Raise
summary: New funds could value facial-recognition company at $9.5 billion. One of China's largest facial-recognition companies is testing the waters for a $1 billion capital raise, according to people familiar with the matter, at a time when governments and businesses are making increasing use of surveillance technology during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Imerys Unit Proposes Bankruptcy Plan to Resolve Cancer Lawsuits
summary: France-based company is selling its U.S. talc mines, which historically supplied Johnson & Johnson. France-based Imerys SA is offering to sell a bankrupt North American unit that was historically a major supplier of talc to Johnson & Johnson in an effort to escape litigation linking its products to ovarian cancer and mesothelioma.

title: Oil Logs Big Weekly Gain Ahead of Contract Expiration
summary: As lockdown measures ease, fuel demand is set to rise, but the path to recovery will be tricky. Oil prices rose Friday, continuing a recent rebound with global fuel demand starting to rise as the world reopens for business.

title: Fleeing Covid Scylla to Economic Charybdis
summary: The governments' responses to the virus will kill us if the virus doesn't.. Regarding your editorial "The Economic Lockdown Catastrophe" (May 9): My protest that we were torching the house to rid it of spiders ("Balancing Covid-19 With a Destructive Cure," Letters, March 26) may have underestimated the severity and the rate at which the Covid-19 virus can spread. However, I stand by my statement that the governments' responses to the virus will kill us if the virus doesn't.

title: Penetrating the Fog of War, Covid-19 Style
summary: Operating-room personnel wearing face masks and glasses have long known that the best way to mitigate the problem of fogging lenses is simply to place a strip of tape along the upper border of the mask and over the bridge of the nose.. Regarding "Before Lifting Lockdowns, Let's Please Unfog Our Glasses" (Page One, May 9): The strategy of using a straw to unfog glasses while wearing a mask works, but it is dangerous. By doing so, one bypasses the entire argument for wearing a mask. This method creates a way to increase the velocity and distance of expelled, unfiltered breath. Others are will be at greater risk, the person who uses a straw with a mask is at greater risk of inhaling the unfiltered breath of others, and the mask is rendered a useless, decorative item.

title: Former New Jersey Governor Campaign Volunteer Settles Assault Lawsuit for $1 Million
summary: Al Alvarez to take antiharassment class, does not admit to wrongdoing in settlement with Katie Brennan. A volunteer for New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy's 2017 campaign who accused one of his staffers of sexual assault settled for $1 million her lawsuit against the campaign, the state and the man she says attacked her.

title: Hulu's Stylish Hatchet Job on Phyllis Schlafly
summary: 'Mrs. America' invents character flaws, but at least Cate Blanchett captures her magnetism.. During her decade-long fight to defeat the Equal Rights Amendment, Phyllis Schlafly liked to say that the ERA "would impose a doctrinaire equality" on the sexes, eliminating the rights and privileges women already had. It's a good line, one the sublime actress Cate Blanchett repeats in "Mrs. America," the FX on Hulu miniseries in which she portrays Schlafly. Nearly a half-century later, it's hard to dispute its essential truth.

title: Congress Eyes Military-Style Budget Carve-Out for Pandemic Prep
summary: Bipartisan lawmakers look hard at setting up health funds that would flow every year; Iowa Rep. Steve King faces GOP primary peril. CONGRESS LOOKS TO MAKE PANDEMIC PREP PERMANENT through an appropriations mechanism used for some military funding. The relatively quiet effort by senior appropriators, endorsed by senior members of both parties, is playing out below the din of recrimination between the Trump administration and members of the Obama administration about who is to blame for shortcomings in the U.S. coronavirus pandemic response.

title: A Virtual Homecoming for Lost Treasures
summary: Digital Benin, a new online database, will track thousands of objects looted from the West African kingdom.. For nearly 100 years, two carved ivory leopards with spots of inlaid bronze have stood tail to tail in London's British Museum. They were seized by British troops from the royal court of the Kingdom of Benin, now part of present-day Nigeria, in 1897, and presented to Queen Victoria by the leader of the expedition.

title: Ahold Delhaize Accelerates Automation as Coronavirus Pressures Workforce
summary: The grocery giant moved up the timeline for development of robotic technologies that can clean stores and process orders. BRUSSELS-Grocer Koninklijke Ahold Delhaize NV says it is accelerating development of robotic technologies because Covid-19 created an urgent need for technology to help workers clean stores and process orders.

title: Be 100% Skeptical of 100% Coronavirus Cure
summary: Sorrento Therapeutics claims it has a cure for the new coronavirus, sending its stock surging. When fears of a pandemic's effects take over the public consciousness, unusual things start to happen. That is especially true for biotech stocks.

title: Virus Bolsters Car Ownership as Consumers Rethink Shared Rides
summary: As ride-hailing hits the skids amid the pandemic, auto makers see renewed interest in personal vehicles. For years, auto makers and investors pumped billions of dollars into new ride-hailing and car-sharing companies, predicting the rise of these ventures would eventually lead their core business of selling vehicles to decline.

title: Fieldwood Energy Prepares for Second Bankruptcy in Two Years
summary: Offshore driller hires Weil Gotshal and AlixPartners to restructure $1.8 billion worth of debt. Fieldwood Energy LLC, an offshore oil driller that operates in the Gulf of Mexico, is preparing for its second stint in bankruptcy in two years after succumbing to plunging energy demand due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Facebook Buys Giphy, Will Make It Part of Instagram Operations
summary: The popular online platform lets users search for animated pictures. Facebook Inc. is buying Giphy, a popular online platform where users can search for animated pictures.

title: Ultra Petroleum Files for Bankruptcy for Second Time in Four Years
summary: Oil and natural-gas driller, which emerged from chapter 11 in 2017, is back in bankruptcy with a plan to cut $2 billion in debt. Ultra Petroleum Corp. , one of the largest oil and natural-gas drillers in Wyoming, filed for bankruptcy Friday, after struggling with nearly $2 billion of debt left on its books after its previous restructuring amid a historic slump in energy prices.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Setting New Driving Hours; FedEx's Retail Limits; Freight Trains from China
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Ex-Republican Helps Put Kansas Senate Seat in Play for Democrats
summary: Barbara Bollier crossed over and hopes enough voters do the same in November; Republicans say she's too liberal to win in Kansas. Democratic Senate candidate Barbara Bollier opened a recent telephone town hall in Kansas with a confession: She used to be a Republican.

title: Power Struggle at Russian Newspaper Shows Kremlin's Widening Influence
summary: One of the country's last independent voices could soon be stifled as Putin expands political control. MOSCOW-A power struggle at the top of Russia's leading business newspaper threatens to stifle one of the country's last remaining independent voices as censorship and the Kremlin's own influence steadily widens.

title: The Often Distorted Reality of Hate Crime in America
summary: Racism remains a blight, but one-sided reporting and misrepresented facts don't help. You will have heard by now of Ahmaud Arbery, the 25-year-old black man shot dead on a street outside Brunswick, Ga., in February. Prosecutors initially declined to press charges in the case, saying that the alleged perpetrators, a white father and son, Gregory and Travis McMichael, had used legitimate force. Then video surfaced of the incident in which the unarmed black man is seen running down the street, seems to be confronted by the McMichaels, and is shot at point-blank range by the men, both of whom have now been charged with murder.

title: Sales Report Puts the Second Quarter in a Deep Hole
summary: After April's slump in retail sales, even pessimistic forecasts for the current quarter could be too upbeat. Economists already had some extremely bearish forecasts for what the economy was going to do in the second quarter. But Friday's retail-sales report quickly made them seem pollyannaish.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Inmates' Request for Texas Prison to Reinstate Coronavirus Measures
summary: Appeals court had blocked precautions ordered by federal judge in Houston. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Supreme Court Thursday rejected an inmate request to reinstate special precautions against the coronavirus a federal judge had ordered for a Texas prison, siding with state officials who argued they had taken adequate measures.

title: A Structural Resurrection
summary: When Michelangelo took over the construction of St. Peter's Basilica, it was a mess. But he turned it into an icon.. We think of Michelangelo as the lone genius who carved the David, the Pietà, and painted the Sistine ceiling. Legend leaves out more than 50 years of Michelangelo's life and work-completing the Tomb of Pope Julius II, painting the Last Judgment and Pauline Chapel frescoes, as well as creating his greatest masterpiece: St. Peter's Basilica.

title: Brexit Talks Go Nowhere, Adding New European Economic Headache
summary: Britain, EU haven't agreed on even basic elements of complex accord that must be settled by year's end. BRUSSELS-A further round of Brexit talks ended in a stalemate Friday, adding another economic anxiety in a region already battered by the coronavirus.

title: Vice Media to Lay Off More Than 150 Employees
summary: Cuts come as company is anticipating stress on its digital advertising business from the pandemic. Vice Media Group on Friday said it is laying off more than 150 employees from its U.S. and international units as the company tries to rein in costs amid an industrywide slowdown in digital advertising.

title: Biden's #MeToo Blunder
summary: The former vice president just made it much harder for friends to support him.. Did Joe Biden just destroy the premise of his presidential campaign? In a single moment in a Thursday night television interview, the former vice president encouraged a significant number of his supporters to abandon him. He also undercut his main argument against President Donald Trump.

title: Hong Kong Watchdog Backs Police Use of Force; Opponents Say 'It's a Joke'
summary: The IPCC reviewed incidents that attracted hundreds of complaints, accusing officers of widespread abuse during last year's protests. HONG KONG-An official watchdog group released a long-awaited report that largely exonerated the use of force by police to suppress antigovernment protests, sparking anger among opposition groups who said the findings reinforce the idea that police aren't accountable to the people.

title: Are Kitchen Pot Racks Best Left Hanging in the 1980s?
summary: We weigh the pros and cons of the highly visible, highly clanky home-chef storage solution. THEY WERE THE VANGUARD of a trend that still dominates today: home kitchens that emulate those in professional restaurants. In a retrospective for the National Kitchen and Bath Association, designer and kitchen historian Ellen Cheever noted that, by the status-craving 1980s, manufacturers were catering to "gourmet cooks." Chef Wolfgang Puck became a celebrity. The word "foodie" was born.

title: SEC Order Finds Morningstar Mixed Analytical Functions With Sales and Marketing
summary: The credit-rating agency will pay $3.5 million to settle charges that it violated a conflict-of-interest rule. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday said credit-rating agency Morningstar Credit Ratings LLC will pay $3.5 million to settle charges that it violated a conflict-of-interest rule by mixing analytical operations with sales and marketing efforts.

title: Greg Laurie Moves His Ministry Online
summary: A megachurch pastor who has spoken out against churches holding in-person services is urging his followers to turn their 'worry into worship'. Back in the 1960s, Greg Laurie was a long-haired hippie who smoked marijuana, took LSD and called Christians at his high school "Jesus freaks." Today, Mr. Laurie is one of the country's best-known megachurch pastors, with a congregation of 15,000 people spread across five campuses in California and Hawaii. His sermons often highlight his belief that no one is beyond redemption.

title: Google Hides News, Tricked by Fake Claims
summary: Resume Subscription. A Google search, at one time, could locate a news article on a man accused of attempted child rape, another on someone charged with fraud and still others on Ukrainian politicians facing corruption allegations. Googling certain keywords in March would find an article detailing the movements of two coronavirus-infected British tourists in Vietnam and warning others who visited the same places to take precautions.

title: Corporate America's Most Underrated Innovation Strategy: 3M's 15% Rule
summary: We often celebrate startups as beacons of innovation. But a sprawling old conglomerate from Minnesota has a lot to teach the new kids.. I met Devendra and Satyendra Kumar 15 years ago at a lab near my house. They worked for Dana Corp. , a supplier of parts for semi trucks, buses and SUVs, but their project was space-age.

title: 'Overhedging' Oil Prices Lands Some Global Airlines in Trouble
summary: The collapse in fuel prices disrupts company moves aimed at smoothing out turbulence in the energy markets. As global airlines reel from the huge drop-off in business caused by the coronavirus, some face a second hit from this year's historic plunge in oil prices.

title: 'Sons of the Waves' Review: Jack Tar: His Own Story
summary: Samuel Johnson remarked that serving on a ship was like being in a jail 'with the chance of being drowned.'. For most of Britain's storied age of sail, climaxing in the Napoleonic Wars (1803-15), the Royal Navy "ruled the waves," to bend a line from James Thomson's rousing song. While sea lanes stayed open for trade, home waters were barred to foreign invasion. As an island nation, with no point more than 70 miles from the sea, the realm's survival depended upon naval supremacy. For nearly two of every three years from 1739 to 1815, Britain was at war. Defeats suffered by ships of the line were few and fleeting. Following the navy's failure to thwart Cornwallis's surrender at Yorktown in 1781, this catastrophic loss, coupled with fears of a cross-channel attack from France, propelled an aggressive program of repairs and new construction, restoring, once more, British dominance at sea.

title: Innovation Can't Be Forced, but It Can Be Quashed
summary: To solve 21st-century problems, innovators need the freedom to experiment without the burden of overregulation and the abuse of intellectual property rights by vested interests. The Covid-19 pandemic reveals that far from living in an age of incessant technological change, we have been neglecting innovation in exactly the areas where we most need it. Faced with a 17th-century plague, we are left to fall back mainly on the 17th-century response of quarantine and closing the theaters.

title: Judge Sullivan Is No Stranger to Politically Flammable Cases
summary: Flynn case jurist has criticized Hillary Clinton, excoriated the IRS and presided over the toppling of a major corruption prosecution. WASHINGTON-In 2018, Michael Flynn was hoping to be sentenced after pleading guilty to one charge of lying to the FBI so he could take his punishment and get on with his life, his lawyers told U.S. District Judge Emmet G. Sullivan. Prosecutors had recommended he receive probation.

title: When Failure Is an Option: A Trading Tactic Soaks Investors
summary: Who doesn't love getting to YES? Turns out some UBS clients have regrets about the firm's Yield Enhancement Strategy.. The catchier an investment's name, the more you should ask: What's the catch?

title: 'Enemy of All Mankind' Review: A Price on His Head
summary: After stealing a fortune from the richest man on earth, Every became the first object of an international manhunt.. On Sept. 11, 1695, a Mughal treasure ship found itself so shrouded in Indian Ocean haze that the lookout failed to sight an English vessel until she was only 5 miles distant. She was coming on very fast-possibly making 15 knots-but this didn't worry the captain of the Ganj-i-sawai (Anglicized into Gunsway in the copious accounts that were to follow): His ship mounted 80 guns; he commanded 400 musketeers and had 1,000 men aboard.

title: The Tragic Fate of Lavish Big Tech Headquarters
summary: Some of the Silicon Valley firms enabling employees to work from home have invested in plush physical offices. If you think empty airplanes sitting dormant on the tarmac sound sad, imagine lavish headquarters idling in Silicon Valley.

title: The Perfect Prank for These Times: Ding-Dong Ditch Is Back
summary: Coronavirus lockdowns fuel a return of childhood game-with a twist. Grownups get a much-needed dose of nostalgia and mischief; 'that buildup of anticipation'. On a recent Sunday, 57-year-old Melinda Hall spent seven hours playing ding-dong ditch, hitting 28 houses.

title: Swiss Watchmaker Calls Time on Luxury Bulls
summary: Cartier owner Richemont missed profit expectations and cut its dividend in a sign of the difficulties that lie ahead even for the strongest brands. Another dividend cut in the cash-rich luxury sector is a warning to investors betting on a rapid rebound-even from a company known for its conservatism.

title: Car Makers See Chinese Market Picking Up, Leaving U.S. and Others Behind
summary: Industry fears the split could endure as mature markets in the West battle fresh economic headwinds and long-term structural challenges. BERLIN- Volkswagen AG , the world's biggest car maker, saw its global sales shrink by almost half in April, but as coronavirus lockdowns in the U.S. and Europe stunted demand the reopening of China's economy offered signs of recovery.

title: Inside Boris Johnson's Tangle With Covid-19
summary: Resume Subscription. LONDON-In a side room of St Thomas' Hospital in central London, doctors faced a decision. Prime Minister Boris Johnson lay sick in the hospital's east wing, struggling to get enough oxygen. Doctors were thinking of putting him on a ventilator, a step that is often a last resort for Covid-19 patients.

title: Ken Melrose Revitalized Lawn-Mower Maker Toro
summary: Long-serving CEO followed principles of servant leadership. Ken Melrose had earned degrees from Princeton, MIT and the University of Chicago when he joined Toro Co. in 1970. "I thought, 'Well, maybe I can sell lawn mowers for a year or two until I find a real job,'" he said later.

title: Two on Philip Roth: How the Lion Groomed His Cubs
summary: Roth dropped hints that he wouldn't be averse to friendly memoirs: 'Maybe write a book about our friendship.'. Any major public figure approaching old age will worry about posterity. Who will write the biography? Who will record and pass judgment on the inevitable vicissitudes, stupidities and sins of a long and eventful life? Is there anything one can do to control the process?

title: Fiction: Can There Be Art Without Artifice?
summary: Auto-fiction, when taken to its stylistic extreme, is not fiction but a record of the writing process.. In her novel"Drifts" (Riverhead, 327 pages, $26), Kate Zambreno reproduces a quote from the obituary of an art critic-unnamed, but it was John Perreault-who had resumed painting late in life, explaining: "Although my guess is that the art 'object' is done with, I myself still go on making 'paintings,' but this doesn't have much to do with making salable physical objects. Making them is more like philosophical investigations, art criticism, or yoga."

title: 'A Children's Bible' Review: Didn't It Rain, Children?
summary: As waters rise, plucky kids save themselves while grown-ups parse the damage clause of their summer lease.. Lydia Millet's novels wear their darkness lightly. She is just so funny (in a wry, tannin-dry sort of way), her observations are so sharp, and her details so absurd (mermaids, mysterious voices, mansions filled with taxidermy), that one can almost forget the fundamental seriousness of her themes. Her stories often consider our solipsism and short-sightedness, the deviousness of politicians and the destruction of our planet. But please don't be daunted by this grim list. Ms. Millet does not sermonize. Even at its gloomiest, her fiction is a pleasure.

title: Children's Books: Summer Is a-Comin' In
summary: Sandcastles, camping trips, sprinklers and lawn mowers.. Cold snaps aside, summertime is almost here. Kevin Henkes evokes it in a picture book: "Summer Song" (Greenwillow, 40 pages, $18.99). "If there is tall grass in a field and the wind blows, it sounds like music," Mr. Henkes writes. "So do the air conditioners and the fans and the sprinklers and the lawn mowers."

title: Mysteries: The Bookseller and the FBI Agent
summary: A bookstore owner draws up a list of 'perfect' crimes from fiction-then learns that a killer may be making them happen in real life.. Malcolm Kershaw, the narrator of Peter Swanson's "Eight Perfect Murders" (Morrow, 270 pages, $27.99), owns a mystery bookstore in Boston. Years ago, he compiled a blog-list of crime novels in which the perpetrator "comes closest to realizing that platonic ideal of a perfect murder." This bibliographic compilation ran from Golden Age titles to hard-boiled works and psychological thrillers. Imagine Malcolm's surprise, then, when FBI Special Agent Gwen Mulvey shows up to suggest that a killer is now using that very list to commit a series of true-life homicides.

title: Five Best: Lawrence Wright on Pandemics in Fact and Fiction
summary: From the author, most recently, of the novel 'The End of October.'. By Barbara W. Tuchman (1978)

title: Industrial Production in U.S. Fell 11.2% in April
summary: Measure of factory, mining and utility output has steepest drop in records dating back 101 years. U.S. industrial production posted the steepest one-month fall on record in April as efforts to control the coronavirus pandemic closed factories, sapped demand and froze global supply chains.

title: Will the Office of the Future Be Different? I Doubt It
summary: They can build bubbles and new schedules, but some old habits are likely to return. I keep reading that because of this crisis, the office of the future will be different, that we are all going to have to show up every other day, sit in enclosed space bubbles, eat lunch alone and ride elevators by ourselves. Stop me when any of this sounds bad. The office of the future sounds pretty much like heaven. Show up every other day? An elevator all to myself? That has been my dream for decades. Granted, I may have to wait in a two-hour line to ride it, but still...Worth it!

title: Ansun Seeking to Reprise Chinese Covid-19 Drug Trial Results in U.S.
summary: Drug that helped clear Covid-19 symptoms in trial of four Chinese patients is now in a U.S. study. When the coronavirus pandemic shook up Ansun Biopharma Inc.'s clinical-trial plans, company leaders knew they had to change course.

title: Coronavirus Pandemic Scrambles Private-Equity Valuations
summary: Private company valuations have been hampered by volatile stock markets, minimal deal activity and uncertainty over how long the pandemic will last. Investors in private-equity funds are focusing more intently on how fund managers value their assets as they brace for further markdowns in their portfolios over the next quarter or two. Some are questioning how much they can rely on the valuations they receive from managers as the coronavirus pandemic continues.

title: Germany Enters Recession but Fares Better Than Neighbors
summary: Data show the divergent economic fortunes of major European countries. FRANKFURT-Germany fell into recession in the first quarter, shrinking at its second-fastest pace since reunification as the coronavirus pandemic bit into everything from retailers to auto exporters, but Europe's powerhouse economy is nonetheless expected to fare better than its neighbors over the balance of 2020.

title: Emma Straub on How Coronavirus Has Turned Contemporary Fiction Into Fantasy
summary: The author of 'Modern Lovers' and co-owner of Brooklyn's Books Are Magic returns with 'All Adults Here'. Known for her astute observations about modern life and her ability to represent a large cast of characters with empathy and amusement, Emma Straub is a perfect novelist for summer reading. Taken together, her last three novels make a mini-genre unto their own-the pleasantly dysfunctional family drama, the kind of novel in which there are plenty of secrets and lots of differing perspectives but things tend to work out well enough in the end.

title: How French Banks Lost Big in the Complex World of Structured Finance
summary: Structured products had been big money earners for BNP Paribas and Société Générale. But the banks have been among Europe's worst-hit financial stocks this year.. France's biggest banks reported substantial trading losses in recent weeks, highlighting the risks they have accumulated selling complex investment products promising high returns when markets are calm.

title: Nostalgia Boosts Baseball Cards of the '80s and '90s
summary: Ken Griffey Jr. has been retired for a decade but his 1989 rookie Upper Deck card has doubled in value since March. The coronavirus has turned baseball into a mere memory. But the combination of sheltering in place and eBay has made a hot commodity out of something sports collectors normally refer to as "junk wax": baseball cards of the 1980s and 1990s.

title: Pandemic Insurance for Poor Countries Pays Out $195.8 Million
summary: Two months after the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a global pandemic, a 'cat bond' will help buy drugs, gear and other aid. A novel pandemic bond is paying out, delivering money for Covid-19 health care in some of the world's poorest countries and providing lessons that big investors will scrutinize for future iterations of the security.

title: SoftBank's Big Bets Are Hit Hard by Coronavirus
summary: Coming earnings will show impact of steep declines in WeWork, Oyo and other top holdings. The world's biggest tech fund was risky from the start, quickly pouring about $80 billion into cash-burning startups at high prices. A less-noticed part of SoftBank Group Corp.'s strategy has deepened the fund's losses and will likely weigh on any recovery.

title: Golf Courses Are Open-But Bring Your Own Gatorade
summary: Courses around the country are mostly open again, but the ground rules have changed. On the bright side: homebound golfers score a few new advantages.. SWIRLING FRESH air? Gatherings no bigger than a foursome? And a capital way to eat up a half-day otherwise lost to Netflix and navel-gazing? Golfing in the great outdoors during these fraught times seems like the last refuge from the ravages of the coronavirus. Across the nation, over 90% of the golf courses that were closed in March and April have now reopened (though some counties' courses and private clubs remain off-limits).

title: After the Market Panic, the Drip, Drip, Drip of Bad News
summary: Stocks are slowly starting to price in the post-lockdown economic malaise. This could be a painful process for investors.. Back in March, the fastest bear market in history triggered widespread panic among investors. This week's wobbles are far less dramatic, but perhaps no less worrying.

title: Japan's Juicy Bank Dividends Defy a Perfect Storm of Profit Pressure
summary: The banks' strategy of roaming overseas for returns has suffered this year, leaving generous dividends the last point of attraction for their stocks. Major Japanese banks are being squeezed hard by economic developments both domestically and overseas. Their generous dividends are still attractive-but are the last real selling points for the stocks.

title: 'Ghost Games' and Swab Tests: German Soccer Finds a Way Back
summary: The German Bundesliga will pick up its season this weekend after a two-month break. No matter what happens now, the league is determined to finish.. The plan to put German soccer back on the field this weekend hinged on more moving parts than a Volkswagen . Clubs had to conduct more than 2,000 coronavirus tests. Chancellor Angela Merkel needed to give her blessing. The Bundesliga drew up a protocol to disinfect balls mid-game.

title: Chinese Stranded Abroad by Coronavirus Turn Ire on Beijing
summary: Many overseas Chinese have flooded embassy hotlines and staged protests in hopes Beijing will intervene to solve situation they blame it for creating. China's ruling Communist Party faces a new chorus of criticism from abroad over its handling of the coronavirus pandemic. This time, it comes from a source that is hard to brush aside: angry Chinese citizens stuck overseas.

title: The Milkman Is Back: Covid Lockdowns Rekindle Demand for Dairy Delivery
summary: Doug Wade resurrects home service after decadeslong hiatus, tries to keep up with Americans' changing tastes. Some wonder if the new business model is worth the investment.. The glass bottles are gone. The cream-topped milk of yore has been replaced by oat milk, almond milk and even a Snickers-flavored drink. But the milkman is back, summoned by customers eager for home delivery in a world changed by pandemic.

title: Coronavirus to Slow U.S. Meat Production for Months, CEO Says
summary: Head of the biggest U.S. beef producer says JBS is revamping operations and has hired 1,000 workers to do extra cleaning. The coronavirus will likely hamper U.S. meat production for months, as new safety measures and reduced staffing slow plant operations, said the head of the biggest U.S. beef producer.

title: Ex-Green Beret Thought U.S. Supported Raid, Family Says
summary: Luke Denman's loved ones plead for State Department's help after mission ends in disaster. WASHINGTON-Luke Denman, a former Green Beret, was searching for meaning after serving in places including Iraq when a former teammate in the U.S. Army Special Forces offered what sounded like a job to help Venezuelans.

title: Apple Supplier Foxconn, Hit By Coronavirus, Posts 90% Profit Drop
summary: Foxconn closed its plants during the coronavirus outbreak in China. Foxconn Technology Group , Apple Inc.'s biggest supplier, was the latest global manufacturer whose profit was dented by the coronavirus pandemic, posting a 90% year-over-year decline in the first quarter after it shut down plants in China for weeks during that period.

title: China Is Powering Up Again. That Might Not Be a Good Thing.
summary: For years, Beijing kept a tight rein on new investment in China's bloated power sector. Not anymore.. Beijing spent much of the past three years cracking down on wasteful infrastructure spending by local governments. Then came the coronavirus.

title: How to Send a Care Package That Really Hits the Mark
summary: The care package has a fascinating history. Now, with so many in need of a meal or simply a diversion, it's back in a big way.. HOMEMADE chocolate-chip cookies, microwave popcorn, maybe a jar of Cheez Whiz: These were the staples of summer-camp and college care packages for those of us of a certain age. The boxes contained more treats than necessities, though I do recall my grandmother sending several cans of tuna to my sister who had just moved to New York City-in case she couldn't find any there.

title: Who's on the Hook for Skipped Mortgage Payments?
summary: Millions of Americans now have the right to postpone mortgage payments. That's a big deal for the complex ecosystem behind home loans.. Covid-19 has turned many investors into amateur epidemiologists. They might also want a crash course in another complex subject: how mortgage payments work.

title: The Numerical Language of Covid-19: A Primer
summary: Understanding terms like R0, R and herd immunity is vital to understanding spread of pandemic. As Covid-19 has swept the globe, a confusing array of numbers has been unleashed along with the virus.

title: This Japanese Region Has No Coronavirus
summary: Iwate, hit by a tsunami in 2011, is alone among nation's 47 prefectures with no reports of Covid-19 among its 1.3 million residents. Four months into the coronavirus pandemic, all but around a dozen remote islands and isolated nations have reported cases of infection. Inside many countries the virus is widespread: Every U.S. state, Chinese province, Italian region and Brazilian state has had Covid-19 patients.

title: This Week's Winners and Losers in the Stock Market
summary: The possibility of a 'V-shaped recovery' is looking more remote, but not every stock this week was a loser. For weeks, skeptical market observers have been asking: Why are stocks rising? The rally seemed particularly at odds with the backdrop of a global pandemic and the worst economy in decades.

title: Emptying Offices Prompt Adoption of Low-Code to Build Work Apps
summary: A simple, visual method of building applications has gained popularity as business with remote workforces look to automate. The shift to remote work has led some companies to come up with quick digital solutions for tasks that have become hard to tackle during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Employment Shock Hits Women Harder Than Men
summary: Women are more likely to work in vulnerable sectors like retailing and personal care. Women usually fare better than men during an economic downturn. Not this time.

title: U.S. Agencies Issue Sanctions Compliance Guidance for Maritime Industry
summary: The industry may need new procedures to avoid being exploited by illicit actors, agencies say. Three U.S. agencies said on Thursday the global maritime industry may need to develop procedures to avoid being exploited by alleged terrorists and other illicit actors seeking to trade with countries subject to U.S. sanctions.

title: Chinese Economy's Recovery From Coronavirus Starts Off Slowly
summary: Industrial output rebounded in April, but unemployment worsened and retail sales fell further than expected. BEIJING-China's economic activity showed some signs of improvement in April as the first country hit by the coronavirus began returning to work, though rising joblessness continued to weigh heavily on consumer spending.

title: Christie's Passes the Digital Gavel in New Relay-Style Sale
summary: To avoid risk of coronavirus, objects will be offered online during 'One: A Global Sale of the 20th Century'. Christie's, the world's biggest auction house, is upending its New York sales calendar once again because it says global bidders won't be able or willing to crowd into a saleroom anytime soon.

title: Don't Stand So Close to Me: AI Cameras Police Social Distancing at Work
summary: Coronavirus concerns lead companies to repurpose sensors that monitor office space, but privacy experts worry about mission creep. Cybersecurity firm Rapid7 Inc. last year installed tiny cameras around its Austin, Texas, office to track how its staff used the space. Now it's using those same cameras to keep workers apart.

title: U.S. Deaths Are Up Sharply, Though Covid-19's Precise Toll Is Murky
summary: Disease caused by the new coronavirus is a leading cause of death in the U.S., especially among middle-aged men and blacks. In mid-April, 30% more Americans died than was typical in the same period in previous years, a Wall Street Journal examination of federal death-certificate data shows.

title: Doctors Are Tweeting About Coronavirus to Make Facts Go Viral
summary: As dubious Covid-19 claims circulate online, UCSF's Dr. Bob Wachter and others are taking to Twitter. SAN FRANCISCO-Bob Wachter, the chairman of the department of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, has had a front-row seat to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Taiwan Firm to Build Chip Factory in U.S.
summary: Plans for TSMC's Arizona plant come as Trump seeks to cut dependence on Asia. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. , the world's largest contract manufacturer of silicon chips, said Friday it would spend $12 billion to build a chip factory in Arizona, as U.S. concerns grow about dependence on Asia for the critical technology.

title: Abbott Will Change Test Instructions for Second Time
summary: Preliminary study by major medical center finds device frequently gives incorrect negative results. Abbott Laboratories said Thursday that it would change the instructions for using its fast coronavirus test for a second time, days after a preliminary study by a major medical center found the device frequently gave negative results for patients who were infected with the virus.

title: Sen. Burr to Step Aside as Intelligence Panel Chairman While Facing Stock-Trade Probe
summary: Move comes after FBI seized North Carolina Republican's cellphone as part of investigation. WASHINGTON-Sen. Richard Burr will temporarily step down as the chairman of the high-profile Senate Intelligence Committee after FBI agents seized his cellphone in their investigation of stock trades he made shortly before the coronavirus roiled markets.

title: Coronavirus Response Exposes Friction Between Top NYC Officials
summary: Last week, mayor took testing program away from city's health commissioner, who had clashed with police chief over PPE. A spat over protective masks for police officers has exposed simmering tensions between top New York City officials over the handling of the coronavirus crisis.

title: Apple Buys Virtual-Reality Streaming Upstart NextVR
summary: NextVR says on its website that it is 'heading in a new direction' after becoming latest Apple acquisition in VR and AR space. Apple Inc. has acquired virtual-reality streaming company NextVR Inc., a signal of the tech giant's continued ambitions in virtual- and augmented-reality technologies.

title: Nissan's U.S. Chief José Luis Valls Resigns
summary: Nissan's U.S. sales fell more than 14% between April 2019 to March 2020. TOKYO- Nissan Motor Co. 's U.S. chief, José Luis Valls, is resigning after a year on the job, the company said.
